title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Sir John, of Fettercairn, i.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: [360] Eldest daughter of David, sixth Earl of Leven and fifth ofMelville, and widow of Sir John Wishart Belsches Stuart, Bart., ofFettercairn.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Thelady was "Williamina Belches, sole child and heir of a gentleman who wasa cadet of the ancient family of Invermay, and who afterwards became SirJohn Stuart of Fettercairn." She married Sir William Forbes in 1797 anddied in 1810.--_Life_, vol.

title: John and Betty's Scotch history visit,
author: Williamson, Margaret. [from old catalog]
snippet: One Sunday it began to rain during church service, and Scott offered his umbrella to Margaret,  daughter of Sir John and Lady Jane Stewart of Fettercairn and Invermay.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We went upstairs : the inn was much larger than at Fettercairn, but not nearly so nice and cheerful ; therewas a drawing-room and a dining-room ; and wehad a very good-sized bedroom.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: At a quarter-past seven o'clock we reachedthe small quiet town, or rather village, ofFettercairn, for it was very small — not a creaturestirring, and we got out at the quiet little inn," Ramsay Arms," quite unobserved, and went atonce upstairs.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We had three miles further to drive to Fettercairn, in all 40 miles from Balmoral.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: Second Great Expedition : — To Invermarkand Fettercairn.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: At the twenty-fourth mile from Aberdeen is the Brig of Potarch, where the old south and north road, still used by drovers, crosses to the Cairn o' Mont, Fettercairn,  and Brechin.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: On the right is seen the hill of Garvock, with its tower, and in the immediate vicinity is the village of Fettercairn.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: attachment, to which we owe the tenderest came Sir John Stuart of Fettercairn."

title: A brief account of a tour through some parts of Scotland
author: Hunter, Robert
snippet: The country is very beautifulas we proceed, and its lovely scenery beginsto croAvd upon our AieAV as Ave approach theGannochbridge, about five miles from Fettercairn.

title: A brief account of a tour through some parts of Scotland
author: Hunter, Robert
snippet: Fettercairn lies at the base of the Grampians, upon the boundary betAveen the Highlands and Lowlands.

title: A brief account of a tour through some parts of Scotland
author: Hunter, Robert
snippet: The rattling of our gig causedhim to look round, and Ave recognized thegood humoured highland face of honest JohnGoav, the landlord of the Forbes Arms ofFettercairn.

title: A brief account of a tour through some parts of Scotland
author: Hunter, Robert
snippet: We now proceed on our way to Fettercairn.
